citation.article-title: Sejongia antarctica gen. nov., sp. nov. and Sejongia jeonii sp. nov., isolated from the Antarctic
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Sejongia (Se.jong′i.a. N.L. fem. n. Sejongia named after the King Sejong Station, where the type species was isolated).
Gram-negative, oxidase- and catalase-positive and psychrotolerant.
Cells are rod-shaped with rounded ends, non-motile and do not glide.
Colonies are convex, translucent, circular, glistening, butyrous, yellow with entire margins, becoming mucoid after prolonged incubation on R2A.
Does not adhere to agar plates.
Growth occurs on R2A, AOA, MA, NA and TSA, but not on cetrimide or MacConkey agar.
Growth under microaerobic (with 5–15 % O2 and 5–12 % CO2 created by CampyPak Plus system) and anaerobic (with 4–10 % CO2 created by GasPak Plus system) conditions is weaker than aerobic growth.
Microaerobic growth is better than anaerobic growth.
Growth is observed at pH 6–11 (optimum pH 7–8) and 0–3 % NaCl (optimum 0 %).
Maximum absorption peak of pigment is at 452 nm and the next shoulder peak is at 480 nm.
Predominant cellular fatty acids are 15 : 0 iso (12·2–13·6 %), 15 : 0 anteiso (15·2–24·2 %) and 17 : 1 iso ω9c (8·6–21·3 %).
The type species is Sejongia antarctica.
